G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, Rachel Bennett, and respectfully petitions this Honorable Court pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 208, § 28, and any other applicable authority, for a modification of the existing custody and parenting time order entered by this Court on June 15, 2021, concerning the minor child Sophie Carter (age 9).

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, this Court may modify a judgment relating to custody or parenting time upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and a finding that modification is in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 10(a).proposition: The best interests of the child remain the paramount concern under Massachusetts law.

Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015)
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: The Massachusetts courts have consistently recognized that a substantial geographic change materially altering the logistics of a parenting plan is sufficient grounds for modification.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: Schechter is a removal and custody case, not a modification case. The opinion discusses the Yannas two‑stage ‘real advantage’ test for removal and emphasizes that removal must be to a specific state and be in the child’s best interests, but it does not analyze modification standards or hold that a substantial geographic change or altered logistics of a parenting plan, by itself, is sufficient grounds for modification. Thus it does not establish the proposition that Massachusetts courts have consistently recognized such geographic changes as sufficient grounds for modification.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “A request for removal is governed by G. L. c. 208, § 30… The statutory standard of ‘upon cause shown’ means that removal must be in the best interests of the child. Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985)… In the first stage, the custodial parent must demonstrate… a ‘good, sincere reason for wanting to remove to another jurisdiction’… If the judge makes these threshold determinations, the judge then moves to the second stage… whether… removal is in the best interests of the child.”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: The Massachusetts courts have consistently recognized that a substantial geographic change materially altering the logistics of a parenting plan is sufficient grounds for modification.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: This concurring opinion does not discuss standards for modifying an existing parenting plan based on a substantial geographic change. Instead, it holds that a sole legal parent of a nonmarital child was free to relocate before paternity was adjudicated and that the judge had no authority to order the child (and thus the mother) back to Massachusetts. The opinion emphasizes stability and the limits of judicial power in relocation/removal, not that a geographic move is itself sufficient grounds for modification, and thus does not support the claimed proposition.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: “After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. … This is not a removal case, and Yannas is inapposite. Neither the judge nor the parties has cited to a single case … that gives a judge authority to pull a parent and child unwillingly back to a State where the parent had a prior and unilateral right to leave.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The Massachusetts courts have consistently recognized that a substantial geographic change materially altering the logistics of a parenting plan is sufficient grounds for modification.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The case does discuss relocation as a substantial change in circumstances by quoting the ALI Principles, but it does not state that Massachusetts courts have *consistently recognized* that any substantial geographic change materially altering parenting logistics is itself sufficient grounds for modification. Instead, the opinion emphasizes that relocation triggers a best-interests analysis and may constitute changed circumstances only when it significantly impairs a parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities. The proposition overstates the breadth and consistency of Massachusetts authority and converts a conditional, fact-dependent principle into a categorical rule.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
“The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002)… state in pertinent part:
‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances… only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise…
… (4)(c) If neither parent has been exercising a clear majority of custodial responsibility for the child, the court should modify the plan… in accordance with the child’s best interests, taking into account all relevant factors including the effects of the relocation on the child.’”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The Massachusetts courts have consistently recognized that a substantial geographic change materially altering the logistics of a parenting plan is sufficient grounds for modification.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: Yannas is a removal/relocation case decided in the context of an original divorce and custody judgment, not a post-judgment modification proceeding. The opinion develops and applies the ‘real advantage’ standard under G.L. c. 208, § 30 for allowing a custodial parent to relocate out of the Commonwealth; it does not discuss standards for modification of an existing parenting plan based on a substantial geographic change, nor does it frame relocation as ‘sufficient grounds for modification.’ Thus it does not support the specific proposition about modification practice in Massachusetts courts.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … The interest of the custodial parent in moving must also be assessed… In this process, the first consideration is whether there is a good reason for the move, a ‘real advantage.’”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The best interests of the child remain the paramount concern under Massachusetts law.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely frames custody determinations around the child’s welfare and best interests, stating that this is the governing and paramount consideration. It reverses the custody award because the judge failed to weigh all relevant factors in terms of their effect on the child’s welfare, explicitly rejecting using custody to punish a parent. This directly affirms that, under Massachusetts law, the child’s best interests remain the paramount concern.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed… Such ‘conduct on [his] part cannot be permitted to interfere with the welfare of the child, the paramount and governing consideration.’”

Delmolino v. Nance-Delmolino, 386 Mass..proposition: The best interests of the child remain the paramount concern under Massachusetts law.
Delmolino v. Nance-Delmolino, 386 Mass..case_name: Superintendent of Schools v. Mayor of Leominster
Delmolino v. Nance-Delmolino, 386 Mass..support_reasoning: This opinion is a municipal finance and school budget case and does not address child custody, visitation, or any doctrine concerning the best interests of the child. Nowhere does the court mention or apply a ‘best interests of the child’ standard, nor discuss family-law principles. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that the best interests of the child are the paramount concern under Massachusetts law.

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Courts have repeatedly held that a relocation or logistical change rendering an existing plan impractical constitutes such a material change.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely rejects the idea that relocation, by itself, is a sufficient material and substantial change to justify modifying an existing custody arrangement. The court holds that a request to relocate is distinct from a request to modify custody, and that modification must be based on changed circumstances other than the move. Thus, it does not stand for the broader proposition that a relocation or logistical change rendering an existing plan impractical is itself a material change; it says the opposite in this context.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28… The custody claim must be considered in light of established principles governing custody determinations.”

Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).proposition: Courts have repeatedly held that a relocation or logistical change rendering an existing plan impractical constitutes such a material change.
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).support_reasoning: The opinion is a divorce and custody decision focused on property division, alimony, and custody mechanics. Its only discussion of modification procedure is a narrow point that custody changes must proceed by complaint for modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28, not by motion. It does not address relocation, logistical changes to parenting plans, or material-change standards, so it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition about relocation or logistical changes rendering a plan impractical as a material change.
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “A change in a custody judgment, however, should be made pursuant to a complaint for modification under G. L. c. 208, § 28. If the judge felt that joint legal custody put the children at risk, or was not in their best interests, because of the wife’s worrisome parenting behavior, then the judge should have ordered sole legal custody to the father. She did not have discretion to fashion, even with the agreement of both parents, an alternative plan.”

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Courts have repeatedly held that a relocation or logistical change rendering an existing plan impractical constitutes such a material change.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion deals with recognition of a California registered domestic partnership, legal parentage, custody standards, and attorney’s fees. It does not discuss modification of parenting plans based on relocation, nor does it articulate any rule that a relocation or logistical change making an existing plan impractical constitutes a material change. The word “material change” or similar modification standard is not analyzed in this context, so the case does not support the claimed relocation/material-change proposition.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: The judge found that disrupting the attachment a child has to a parent and behaving in ways designed to alienate a child from that parent causes harm that can be long term, and if sole physical custody must be awarded because of geographic distance between parents, “it is in the best interests of a child to be in the sole custody of the parent who can support the involvement of both parents rather than with the parent who alienates the child from the other parent.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: When circumstances affecting the feasibility or effect of a parenting plan change substantially, the Court must craft a new arrangement that protects the child’s welfare.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The case discusses standards for making and modifying custody orders (best interests vs. substantial change in circumstances) and emphasizes stability and continuity, but it does not hold that upon a substantial change in circumstances the court must craft a new arrangement. In fact, the court expressly declines to apply the substantial change standard, treating the matter as an initial custody determination, and focuses instead on preserving or not disrupting satisfactory existing arrangements. The proposition overstates and mischaracterizes the holding.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: "We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). ... It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20..."

White v. LaGrassa, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 383.raw_text: White v. LaGrassa, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 383 (2011)
White v. LaGrassa, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 383.proposition: When circumstances affecting the feasibility or effect of a parenting plan change substantially, the Court must craft a new arrangement that protects the child’s welfare.
White v. LaGrassa, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 383.case_name: Chief Justice for Administration & Management of the Trial Court v. Commonwealth Employment Relations Board
White v. LaGrassa, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 383.support_reasoning: The case is an employment and labor relations decision about whether the Chief Justice for Administration and Management must bargain over hiring and deploying court officers. It does not address family law, parenting plans, or standards for modifying custody arrangements upon changed circumstances. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition about revising parenting plans to protect a child’s welfare.
White v. LaGrassa, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 383.relevant_excerpt: “This appeal presents the question whether the Chief Justice for Administration and Management of the Trial Court (CJAM) must collectively bargain over the impact of his decisions to hire and deploy court officers for public safety purposes. … For the following reasons, we reverse the decision and order of the board.”
